title: 111_s823
content: The Act is titled the "Net Operating Loss (NOL) Carryback Act" and allows for a 5-year carryback of operating losses. The "Net Operating Loss (NOL) Carryback Act" allows for a 5-year carryback of operating losses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments to section 172(b)(1) include specific provisions for applicable 2008 or 2009 net operating losses. The provision defines the term 'applicable 2008 or 2009 net operating loss' as the taxpayer's operating loss for taxable years ending in 2008 or 2009, or the taxpayer's loss if they elect this option instead. The taxpayer can elect to apply a net operating loss for taxable years in 2008 or 2009, with the election being irrevocable and made by the due date for filing the tax return. This election coordinates with the alternative tax net operating loss deduction. The tax code is amended to allow for the application of net operating losses for specific taxable years, with changes to deductions and loss calculations for certain periods. The tax code is amended to allow for the application of net operating losses for specific taxable years, with changes to deductions and loss calculations for certain periods. The amendment includes provisions for carrying back 2008 and 2009 losses, allowing taxpayers to substitute '5' or '4' for '3' in certain cases. The taxpayer can elect to apply a specific clause for their loss from operations in 2008 or 2009. The election must be made by the due date for filing the tax return and is irrevocable once made. This election coordinates with the alternative tax net operating loss deduction. The Secretary of Treasury will prescribe rules to prevent abuse of the amendments made, including anti-stuffing and anti-churning rules. The amendments apply to net operating losses after December 31, 2007, with the alternative tax net operating loss deduction applying to taxable years after 1997. The amendment made by subsection (b) applies to taxable years ending after 1997, while the amendment made by subsection (d) applies to losses from operations in taxable years ending after December 31, 2007. A transitional rule allows for the revocation of certain elections related to net operating losses before the applicable date. The amendment allows for timely filing of loss applications before the applicable date, defined as 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The amendments do not apply to TARP recipients with equity interests acquired by the Federal Government under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008. The Federal Government acquires warrants or rights to acquire equity interests under the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008. This includes the Federal National Mortgage Association, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, and taxpayers affiliated with those described in the Act.
